title: Parkinson's Disease — Psychosis
icd10: ** F06.0 (Psychotic disorder due to known physiological condition with hallucinations)
F06.2 (Psychotic disorder due to known physiological condition with delusions)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of psychosis in the setting of Parkinson's disease. Covers the full spectrum from minor visual hallucinations (passage hallucinations, presence hallucinations) to formed visual hallucinations, delusions (paranoid, jealousy), and delirium. Includes medication-induced psychosis, PD dementia-related psychosis, and intercurrent medical causes. Addresses the critical tension between treating psychosis (requires dopamine reduction) and maintaining motor function (requires dopamine). Applies to ED (acute psychosis), inpatient (severe, disruptive), and outpatient (chronic management) settings.

— Core Labs (Order for All Patients).rationale: Infection screen (UTI, pneumonia — most common delirium triggers)

— Core Labs (Order for All Patients).item: BMP (Na, K, Cl, CO₂, BUN, Cr, glucose)
— Core Labs (Order for All Patients).rationale: Metabolic derangements (hyponatremia, uremia, hypoglycemia) as cause of altered mental status
UTI — most common precipitant of delirium and acute psychotic worsening in elderly PD patients
Hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism — exacerbates cognitive symptoms
Deficiency contributes to cognitive decline and psychiatric symptoms
Hepatic encephalopathy; drug metabolism assessment (many PD meds hepatically cleared)
Sepsis — common cause of acute psychosis in elderly

— Extended Labs (Order When Clinically I.rationale: If substance use suspected; may detect unexpected medications
Amantadine, lithium, anticonvulsant levels — toxicity can cause psychosis
Hepatic encephalopathy if liver disease suspected
Neurosyphilis — treatable cause of psychosis in appropriate clinical context
If risk factors present — HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder
Adrenal insufficiency — especially if on chronic steroids

— Rare/Specialized Labs.rationale: If atypical course, rapid onset, or young patient — anti-NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2 antibodies
If subacute onset, associated neurologic findings suggesting paraneoplastic process

— Rare/Specialized Labs.item: CSF analysis (cell count, protein, glucose, cytology)
— Rare/Specialized Labs.rationale: Only if infection or autoimmune encephalitis is on differential — not routine for PDP

— Essential Imaging.rationale: Acute change in mental status — rule out stroke, subdural hematoma, hydrocephalus; first-line imaging
Pneumonia screen (common delirium trigger in elderly PD patients)
QTc assessment **before starting pimavanserin** (prolongs QTc); baseline for antipsychotic monitoring

— Extended Imaging.rationale: Structural lesion, stroke, NPH, Lewy body pattern atrophy; indicated if new or atypical psychosis, rapid cognitive decline, or focal neurologic signs
If concern for nonconvulsive seizures or Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; periodic discharges in CJD

— Rare/Specialized Studies.rationale: Only if PD diagnosis is uncertain and DLB vs AD vs PD-D needs clarification; not routinely needed if PD diagnosis established
Research/atypical cases — posterior cortical hypometabolism supports DLB/PDD
Quantify cognitive deficits; distinguish PD-MCI from PDD; track progression; help predict psychosis risk
If RBD evaluation needed or if sleep fragmentation contributing to psychotic symptoms

dosing.instructions: UTI, pneumonia, constipation/fecal impaction, medication changes, hospitalization itself — treat the underlying cause; psychosis may resolve entirely

— Acute / Emergency Treatment.monitoring: Vital signs, urinalysis, CBC, CMP, chest X-ray

dosing.instructions: Systematic deprescribing in order of cognitive risk (stop first → stop last): **anticholinergics** (benztropine, trihexyphenidyl) → **amantadine** → **MAO-B inhibitors** (selegiline, rasagiline) → **dopamine agonists** (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine) → **COMT inhibitors** (entacapone) → **reduce levodopa dose** (last resort — maintain motor function)

— Acute / Emergency Treatment.contraindications: Do not abruptly discontinue dopaminergic agents — risk of neuroleptic malignant-like syndrome
— Acute / Emergency Treatment.monitoring: Motor function (UPDRS); symptom re-assessment after each change

dosing.instructions: Adequate lighting (reduce visual hallucinations), familiar objects, reorientation, sleep hygiene, minimize polypharmacy

— Acute / Emergency Treatment.indication: Acute agitation in PDP — first-line; lowest D2 affinity among available agents

dosing.instructions: start 12.5 mg, may repeat in 2 hours

— Acute / Emergency Treatment.contraindications: Avoid IM formulation; avoid if QTc >500 ms
— Acute / Emergency Treatment.monitoring: Sedation level; QTc; metabolic panel; glucose

— Acute / Emergency Treatment.indication: Severe agitation in PDP — benzodiazepine safer than typical antipsychotic
— Acute / Emergency Treatment.contraindications: Respiratory depression; avoid in severe hepatic impairment
— Acute / Emergency Treatment.monitoring: Sedation level; respiratory rate; fall risk

— First-Line Chronic Treatment.indication: PDP — only FDA-approved medication (2016); selective 5-HT2A inverse agonist; no D2 blockade

dosing.instructions: no titration needed; onset of effect 4-6 weeks

— First-Line Chronic Treatment.contraindications: Avoid if QTc >500 ms; avoid with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
— First-Line Chronic Treatment.monitoring: Baseline ECG and periodic QTc monitoring; no dose adjustment in renal impairment; prior authorization usually required

— First-Line Chronic Treatment.indication: PDP — best-studied alternative to pimavanserin; very low D2 affinity at low doses

dosing.instructions: start 12.5 mg, titrate by 12.5-25 mg every 3-5 days; target lowest effective dose; typical effective range 25-100 mg qhs

— First-Line Chronic Treatment.contraindications: Orthostatic hypotension risk (already a PD issue)
— First-Line Chronic Treatment.monitoring: Metabolic panel; fasting glucose and lipids; weight; orthostatic blood pressure

— Second-Line Treatment.indication: PDP — best evidence for efficacy (Level B, AAN); low D2 affinity; effective at very low doses

dosing.instructions: start 6.25 mg (1/4 of 25 mg tablet), titrate by 6.25 mg every 3-7 days; target 12.5-50 mg/day

— Second-Line Treatment.contraindications: Requires REMS program enrollment; contraindicated if unable to comply with ANC monitoring; risk of agranulocytosis (~1%); risk of myocarditis (rare)
— Second-Line Treatment.monitoring: Mandatory ANC monitoring (weekly x6 months, then biweekly x6 months, then monthly); metabolic panel; fasting glucose and lipids; weight

— Second-Line Treatment.indication: PD dementia with psychosis — addresses cholinergic deficit; may reduce hallucinations (EXPRESS trial)
— Second-Line Treatment.contraindications: GI side effects common with oral; tremor may transiently worsen
— Second-Line Treatment.monitoring: GI tolerability; cognitive testing (MMSE/MoCA); tremor severity

— Refractory Psychosis Management.indication: Severe refractory PDP — limited evidence but used in practice

dosing.instructions: Use pimavanserin + quetiapine (or + clozapine) per individual dosing guidelines above

— Refractory Psychosis Management.contraindications: Additive QTc prolongation risk with pimavanserin + quetiapine; additive sedation
— Refractory Psychosis Management.monitoring: QTc (combined agents); ANC if clozapine included; metabolic panel; sedation level

— Refractory Psychosis Management.indication: Severe PDP refractory to all medications; also improves motor symptoms temporarily

dosing.instructions: Case reports/small series show benefit; logistic and access barriers

— Refractory Psychosis Management.contraindications: Standard ECT contraindications (raised ICP, pheochromocytoma, unstable aneurysm)
— Refractory Psychosis Management.monitoring: Post-procedure cognitive assessment; motor function (UPDRS); seizure duration

— Refractory Psychosis Management.indication: Refractory psychosis — last resort; accept some motor worsening to control psychosis

dosing.instructions: If all else fails, gradually reduce levodopa; family discussion about trade-offs essential

— Refractory Psychosis Management.contraindications: Never abruptly discontinue — risk of neuroleptic malignant-like syndrome
— Refractory Psychosis Management.monitoring: Motor function (UPDRS); psychosis severity; ADL function

— Refractory Psychosis Management.indication: Persistent and dangerous psychosis unresponsive to treatment

dosing.instructions: Consider memory care or psychiatric facility with movement disorder expertise

— Refractory Psychosis Management.monitoring: Safety assessments; psychosis severity; caregiver burden

— Referrals.rationale: PDP medication optimization — balance motor and psychiatric symptoms; pimavanserin initiation; clozapine program enrollment
Severe psychosis, medication-refractory symptoms, ECT evaluation, capacity assessment
Cognitive testing — PD-MCI vs PDD staging; psychosis risk stratification; capacity evaluation
Caregiver support, home safety evaluation, placement assistance if needed
Goals of care discussion if advanced PDD with refractory psychosis — quality of life focus
